theft.question:
Did I intentionally fail to pay my debts? 

This examination concerns your intention, specifically whether you deliberately neglected or omitted paying what was owed to others, in violation of the principle of justice. This is a serious matter that requires careful reflection on your thoughts, words, and actions. In this case, failing to pay debts constitutes a sin against others through omission, specifically theft.
theft.description: Intentionally failing to pay debts is sinful because it violates both the seventh commandment against theft and the principle of justice that requires honoring our commitments to others.

blasphemy.question: Did I receive Holy Communion while knowingly in a state of grave sin, thus showing disrespect for the real presence of Christ?
blasphemy.description: This mortal sin is a form of sacrilege and profanes the real presence of Christ and shows grave disrespect for the sacrament by receiving unworthily.

ambition.question: Did my desire for power and dominance influence the decisions I made about time and attention devoted to family and friends?
ambition.description: inordinate ambition and the obsession with power corrupts the soul by placing our desire to dominate and control above God's authority, turning us away from humble service and toward prideful self-exaltation.

greed.question: Have I made accumulation of money and possessions a driving force in my life, such that it distracts me from trusting God's providence?
greed.description: This sin makes money an idol that replaces trust in God's providence, turning what should be a tool for good into an object of worship.

autonomy.question: Did you take for granted the blessings in your life, forgetting to acknowledge their source in God's providence?
autonomy.description: Believing that one's blessings are due to one's own self-sufficiency and determination is a sin as it is a rejection of recognizing Divine Providence as being ultimately responsible.
